p.s: In following, I am going to analyze the sonnet by taking a closer look at the languge and stylistic devices used in order to convey the message and intention of the sonnet.
In the first line, you can find an enumeration.
The repetition of the things that seem to be undestroyable emphasizes that everything transitory.
The form of the ennumeration could also imitate the sonnet of a clock, which has the intention to show the matter of time to the reaer.
In the second line, you can see the personification [...] mortality o'er-sways their power [...].
This personification intensifies the messagmessage of the first line and shows that even things that seem undestroyable lose their power througtthrough mortality.
In the next line is again a personification.
In connection to the metaphorametaphor and comparing in the next line, it convinces the reader from the transitoriness of beauty.
In line 5 and 6 are two personifications and a metaphorametaphor: [...] how shall summer's honey breath hold out / Against the wrackful siege of batt'ring days [...].
It has the intention to make it clear and imaginable for the reader that summer can notcannot beat the time.
In line ten, the metaphorametaphor [...] time's best jewel [...] should convince the reader that nothing can resist the effects of the time.
In the last line is also a metaphorametaphor.
It emphasizes that writing is important for Shakespeare, even when nothing can beat the time.
In the context of Shakespeare's catalogue of sonnets, the sonnet Sonnet 65 is similar to other sonnets.
Every sonnet has 14 lines where the first 12 lines can be seperatedseparated in three verses of four where Shakespeare gets into a question.
The last couplet which Shakespeare uses as a resolution is similar to other sonnets.
The metre and the rhyme of the sonnet are the same in other sonnets in Shakespeare's catalogue.
Also the theme of the sonnet is fitting in his catalogue.
The most themes are love, death, time and beauty.
